repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fixes #18108

@bfredl, this removes an old part of the code that was added a long
time ago.

Now comes the question of actually using ephemeral extmarks, and
rather use persistent extmarks and rely on tree updates.

I just leave that there...

comment_regular_data.body: Why remove the state between lines? That seems like a pure regression from a performance perspective (also it just is wrong, we redraw a line range, not a line at a time).

> Why remove the state between lines? That seems like a pure regression from a performance perspective (also it just is wrong, we redraw a line range, not a line at a time).

Because, as most of my fellow developer, I don't have a terrifically deep understanding of the drawing loop.

Why not sending the end line in the callback to the redrawing ?
And what about using static extmarks instead of a complex highlight state ? That will make a huge part of the code simpler to understand.

> Because, as most of my fellow developer, I don't have a terrifically deep understanding of the drawing loop.

Any perf related change must be based on "understanding", other wise it is just a random hit or miss. Profiling can help to get empirical understanding (I have used this to get rid of bottlenecks in unexpected places, such as `strequal()` ).

> Why not sending the end line in the callback to the redrawing ?

That's on_win, and could be alternative, but then the hlstate array might get much longer (at the point we could be starting to see `O(n^2)` behavior there, but likely only for real big windows).

> Any perf related change must be based on "understanding", other wise it is just a random hit or miss. Profiling can help to get empirical data.

Running the test showed a slight improvement in performances.

If you don't want the changes, just close that PR, I don't care, I just wanted to raise a point (I did twice) about static extmarks, and you plain ignored it twice.

> If you don't want the changes, just close that PR, I don't care, I just wanted to raise a point (I did twice) about static extmarks, and you plain ignored it twice.

simply because I needed to think a bit more about that? you posted it 37 minutes ago, and I don't see the hurry, sorry. it could be simpler, though I like the current code that it doesn't duplicate state already in the tree in a second static copy, so I think that is a point for simplicity as well.

> I think that is a point for simplicity as well.

That is a valid point. Although I think that this is an instance where this simplicity might lead to a bit too much work on the drawing side.

I think we'd need real data in order to compare this in real life. I remember I did a similar change a while back, and that lead to significant performance improvements.

> That is a valid point. Although I think that this is an instance where this simplicity might lead to a bit too much work on the drawing side.

Sure but OTOH if you pre-render whenever the tree is changed, you do more work upfront instead (which might not end up being used). I suspect the trade-off varies greatly how much text-editing vs scrolling around the user does.
Good point, maybe we need something that redraws the static extmarks in `on_win` ?

@bfredl coming back at this, I am able, with this version of the implementation to limit how far we go on the number of columns.

An even better way of doing this (that I don't know though), would be to pass the very specific byte offsets to the `on_line` callback, so that we only draw the very portion of the line that the user sees.
Thus this version should also fix #14852
Any update on this PR ? I think it is already a step forward in fixing bugs...

I have added the doubling of the match limit value, which should give more room for queries to run.
I think that the PR is ready this way. @bfredl if you want to give a final opinion, I'd be glad to have it.

For the record, this fixes:
https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/issues/1788
https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/issues/1506

Now that we have untangled the correctness from perf aspect, perhaps we could break out the former to a separate PR? I e more or less the changes to treesitter.c (including the free list, as that is more or less obvious)
That is a good idea, if only because the fix should definitely be backported to 0.7.

I am in favor of this, what parts do you want to separate:
- free list + synmaxcol
- iterator reset + doubling?

This way we have the fix on one hand a'd the feature on the other?
I'd say put the kvck and the doubling in a separate `fix(treesitter)` PR.
iterator reset is a perf-only question with sufficient `match_limit` set (as we figured out in dev chat, the "reset" only made behavior deterministic, not always correct).
Hi, any updates on this? This is meant to solve long html highlight problems, right? Now we should disable treesitter for html files otherwise its buggy

Hi, I need to get back to this and mainly rebase on master.
This is not really long but I just need to actually do the work.
I expect to have time for this at some point tomorrow night.

So I have rebased the PR on latest master, and we _just_ need to wait for @bfredl approval here.

I trully think that this is an enhancement over what was previously done by the way.
Hi @bfredl is there anything left to approve this changes?

This still unconditionally discards TS state from one line to the next line _within the same batched redraw_, which i thought we all concluded is not the way forward. (unlike, say,  using guesstimated botline in on_win or cached marks, which would be)
Just to note that this also improves performance for buffers with very large folds since the iterator is re-created for each line.
@vigoux So it seems like this is getting stuck, if i could help somehow

> Just to note that this also improves performance for buffers with very large folds since the iterator is re-created for each line.

Does it _improve_ the performance or degrades it ?

Because if is does improve, this is a direct proof that recreating the iterator is actually better.

> Does it improve the performance or degrades it ?

Improves

@kevinhwang91 noticed that files with very large folds were causing him lag. He initially thought the problem was due to Gitsigns (https://github.com/lewis6991/gitsigns.nvim/issues/575) but then realised it was actually treesitter.

He raised #18760 to fix the specific perf issue he was having by simply creating a new iterator if the current iterators next row is less than the current line being highlighted. However, I pointed him to this PR which he has tested and reports resolves the perf issue too.
Then this also resolves the question of performance, and I see no blockers to this PR appart from a rebase (which I'll do in a sec).

For reference, the testcase from https://github.com/lewis6991/gitsigns.nvim/issues/575 is pretty simple:

> 1. `nvim +'set foldmethod=manual' +'1000,5000fold' +'999' ./src/nvim/eval.c`
> 2. Move cursor up and down
Reproducible, I am going to attempt a little benchmark somehow.
I am somehow not able to reproduce this using `nvim --clean` and that sounds weird to me.
Try making the fold as large as possible.

I finally got a benchmark, as follows:
```bash
VIMRUNTIME=$(pwd)/runtime/ time nvim --clean -u init.lua ./src/nvim/eval.c
```

```lua
-- init.lua
local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(0, "c", {})
local highlighter = vim.treesitter.highlighter.new(parser)

local function keys(keys)
  vim.api.nvim_feedkeys(keys, 't', true)
end

vim.opt.foldmethod = "manual"
vim.opt.lazyredraw = false

vim.cmd [[1000,7000fold]]
vim.cmd [[999]]

local function mk_keys(n)
  local acc = ""
  for i = 1, n do
    acc = acc .. "j"
  end
  for i = 1, n do
    acc = acc .. "k"
  end

  return "qq" .. acc .. "q"
end

keys(mk_keys(10))

for i = 1, 100 do
  keys "@q"
  vim.cmd[[redraw!]]
end

vim.cmd [[quit!]]
```

With this PR : `0:01.10`
Current  `master`: `0:03.11`

That's a 3x improvement in performance.
I suppose the presence of a (large) fold could be detected by comparing difference of `line` param and previous value with some threshold?

What's a "large enough" fold ? I think that the data above is a clear indicator of a perf improvement.
I am working on more benchmarks, in order to bring more proofs of the perf improvement.
idk, as a simple starting point we can just do it for any fold (so whenever delta > 1)

Here's my results using the benchmark above.

|   | Time |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| master  |  `5.168`  |
| This PR | `1.528` |
| #18760  | `0.247`  |

So 3x improvement with this PR, but 20x with #18760!!!

So there's some evidence that re-using the iterator is worth doing.

We really need a dedicated benchmark test suite (`make performancetest`), not necessarily for CI, but both for such performance PRs and for regression testing with `git bisect`. 

A PR or dedicated issue for discussing this welcome!
Ding #18989
I am wondering if this finally gets to master, when will it be available to users? In 0.8 right?
Probably. But #18760 is already in master and backported to the `release-0.7` branch, so will be in 0.7.1 (which should be released soon).
Is there a reason to keep this open? The related issues have been closed, and the code here is likely very out of date.
The one thing this patch does is add support for `synmaxcol`; not really sure how valuable that is since treesitter must parse the whole tree anyway.

Worth noting that with #31324 a move towards static extmarks is made. For `conceal_lines` specifically it is necessary because it affects what lines should be drawn and other editor behavior, but I also find myself wondering why `highlighter.lua` places ephemeral marks whenever I work with it.
@bfredl should be able to say.

> Worth noting that with https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31324 a move towards static extmarks is made.

Not as general principle or necessarily permanent. 

> but I also find myself wondering why highlighter.lua places ephemeral marks whenever I work with it.

Because it gets the job of highlighting done. Having `:syntax` equivalent state visible in the extmark tree was not a goal upon itself (and would be very expensive if done for the entire buffer). 

Not set in stone of course, but needs a _new_ concrete proposal for what should be done instead and why it would be better, rather than necrobumping old complaints that already have been addressed.

> Not as general principle or necessarily permanent.

I guess not, although not placing static conceal_line marks and always querying the syntax tree each time plines code is called seems ill-advised to me.

The proposal in #31324 is to place conceal_marks as the line_height/redraw code comes across them, there is no need to do it for the entire buffer. As long as the buffer text/syntax tree doesn't change those marks are valid. In my mind the same principle could be applied to highlight marks and would just give free scroll performance. 

Sorry for the "necrobump", I was just adding what I thought was relevant information to the recently posted comments, as the static extmark discussion above didn't seem fully resolved to me...

There was no concrete proposal or discussion to resolve in the first place, just a offhand remark that "static extmarks" would make everything magically simpler (spoiler: it won't)

Completely independent of that, we can of course discuss utilizing non-ephemeral marks as a caching layer, but this would need to be proposed (in a dedicated issue/PR, not as a rhetorical backstop for another PR)  with some concrete ideas how this caching would actually work (i e how large regions should be cached and for how long to not waste memory, how do we turn it off while editing is done and it is not really useful, etc etc).

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: refactor(treesitter): rely more on ts correctness
